channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: ‘The Fate of Our Donbas Is Being Decided,’ Zelensky Says of Sievierodonetsk
item.description: From across the river in a twin city, the danger to outgunned Ukrainian forces is clear. The city is burning, and small-arms fire from street-to-street combat echoes across the water.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A couple eating lunch Thursday at a school in Sloviansk that serves free hot meals to those who have stayed behind near the front lines.

item.title: Live Updates: At Americas Summit, Biden Calls for Fighting Poverty, Promoting Regional Progress
item.description: The summit is being held without the heads of Mexico and several other countries in a sign of a growing rift between the United States and Latin American nations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: From the Graveside to the Front, Ukrainians Tell of Grim Endurance
item.description: Ukraine’s casualties in the war against Russia are a closely guarded secret. But those who have been in the trenches along the front line know how relentless the fight has become.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly

item.title: Chinese Pilots Sent a Message. American Allies Said They Went Too Far.
item.description: Australia and Canada said Chinese jets harassed their military planes, though Beijing says it was defending its security. A mishap over Pacific waters could have ominous repercussions.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Taiwan Ministry of Defense, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Chinese J-16 fighter jet, in an undated photo released by Taiwan’s defense ministry. Australia said a J-16 harassed one of its surveillance planes over the South China Sea last month.

item.title: The Racist Researcher Cited in the Buffalo Gunman’s Manifesto
item.description: The work of Michael Woodley, a Briton who was cited by the teenager who killed 10 Black people at a supermarket in Buffalo, included pseudoscientific theories that have been used to justify racism.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert

item.title: Naftali Bennett, Israel’s Prime Minister, Visits U.A.E.
item.description: The trip by Naftali Bennett, the Israeli leader, burnishes his foreign policy credentials and provides some distraction from his domestic political troubles.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: Men Missing in Amazon Faced Threats Before They Disappeared
item.description: Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous groups, have not been seen since Sunday. They faced threats before they disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Ana Ionova and André Spigariol
item.media:description: The journalist Dom Phillips taking notes as he talks with Indigenous people in Roraima State, Brazil, in 2019.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s LIV Golf Series Upends Genteel World of Golf
item.description: By promising top players multimillion-dollar paydays to join its new tour, the kingdom moved beyond investing in a sport and instead made a play for control of one.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Phil Mickelson is one of the prize catches for the new LIV Golf Invitational Series. He reportedly is receiving $200 million to take part.

item.title: At Least 7 Killed in Explosion and Fire in Daegu, South Korea
item.description: A man in his 50s was suspected of setting off the explosion that started the blaze at a law firm’s office in the city of Daegu, the police said. He is believed to have died in the fire.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young, John Yoon and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Police officers at the site of the fire in Daegu, South Korea, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Has Filled Ukrainian Water Canal to Crimea
item.description: Ukraine blocked a freshwater to canal to the Crimean Peninsula after Russia occupied it 2014. Moscow has fully restored the flow, easing its path to a “land bridge” with Russia, images show.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Malachy Browne

item.title: Belgian King Returns Mask to Congo in Landmark Visit
item.description: But so far, the monarch has not apologized for decades of brutal Belgian rule during which up to 10 million Congolese people died.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Felix Tshisekedi, looks at a ceremonial mask handed over by Belgium’s King Philippe at the National Museum of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in Kinshasa on Wednesday.

item.title: In Ukraine, Evacuating the Vulnerable Amid the Terror of War
item.description: As Russian forces bear down on eastern Ukraine, a small army of volunteers is racing to bring to safety those unable to care for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Ivor Prickett and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Car Plows Into a School Group in Berlin, Killing 1 and Injuring 14
item.description: A teacher was killed and those hurt were students traveling with her. The driver was described as “mentally impaired,” and police are investigating whether the crash was intentional.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Police officers and rescue workers at the site where one person was killed and a dozen injured when a car drove into a crowd in Berlin on Wednesday.

item.title: Sewol Ferry Disaster in South Korea Leaves Unhealed Wounds
item.description: Eight years after the Sewol ferry disaster took the lives of 250 South Korean students, parents say they are still struggling to come to terms with the lessons the tragedy brought to bear.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Mi-ok, the mother of Lee Ho-jin, a Sewol ferry victim, reading messages from his friends in his bedroom in Ansan, South Korea. She has kept his room as it was when he died eight years ago.

item.title: Dmitry Kovtun, Accused Killer of Russian Dissident, Dies at 56
item.description: He and another ex-spy were found by British authorities to have served polonium-laced tea in London to an intelligence agent who had defected.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Dmitri Kovtun in 2015. Traces of polonium were found in hotel rooms and other locations that he had occupied, linking him to the murder of a fellow former spy.

item.title: U.S. Accelerated Expulsions of Haitian Migrants in May
item.description: The uptick has rekindled criticism that the Biden administration treats Black migrants differently than others, an allegation it denies.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: Haitians who were deported from the United States arrived in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last year.

item.title: Putin Compares Himself to Peter the Great, the Famous Czar
item.description: Vladimir Putin likened his goals in Ukraine to the conquests of Peter the Great.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin visiting an exhibition celebrating the 350th birthday of Emperor Peter I in Moscow.

item.title: The Best Books to Read on Disinformation: Its History, Techniques and Effects
item.description: The phenomenon has undermined our trust in electoral systems, in vaccines — and in what happened at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Here are books on its history, techniques and effects.
item.dc:creator: Richard Stengel
item.category: The Misinformation Age: How False Beliefs Spread (Book)
Active Measures: The Secret History of Disinformation and Political Warfare (Book)

item.title: Russia Prosecuting 1,100 Captured Ukrainian Soldiers
item.description: Announcing the invasion in February, Vladimir Putin said Ukrainians would be prosecuted for “blood crimes.” Moscow is now making good on that vow.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers who had been fighting in the Azovstal steel plant after surrendering to Russian-backed forces last month.

item.title: Tourist Damages Rome’s Spanish Steps by Pushing a Scooter Down Them
item.description: An American woman and her companion caused $27,000 in damage to the landmark, officials said. They were fined and have been barred from the site for six months.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Spanish Steps, as seen from the Piazza di Spagna in Rome last year.

item.title: German Brewers Face ‘Unprecedented’ Beer Bottle Shortage
item.description: A nation of beer lovers is facing a shortage of bottles, partly because of the war in Ukraine. Breweries are looking to drinkers for a rescue.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bottles filled with beer in Klosterbrauerei Neuzelle’s warehouse don’t come cheap. Their price “has exploded,” the German brewery’s managing director said.

item.title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Arrested in Covid Test Kit Scandal
item.description: The health minister and the mayor of Hanoi were removed from their posts in a scandal that has led to charges against dozens of officials.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen
item.media:description: Testing for covid in Hanoi. The city’s mayor and Vietnam's health minister have been removed from office and arrested over a test kit scandal.

item.title: Covid and Race
item.description: The death rate for white Americans has recently exceeded the rates for Black, Latino and Asian Americans.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clem Williams, 76, receiving her second booster shot in Durham, N.C. in May.

item.title: A Radical Collective Takes Over One of the World’s Biggest Art Shows
item.description: Ruangrupa, an Indonesian group of collaborators, turns social experiences into art. How will they leave their mark on Documenta, which unfolds over 100 days.
item.dc:creator: Samanth Subramanian
item.media:credit: Arne Piepke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ade Darmawan (in orange), a founder of ruangrupa; Ayse Gulec, a member of Documenta’s artistic team; the artist Agus Nur Amal PMTOH (far right); and Agus’s manager, Greistina Kusumaningrum (left, back to camera) preparing for Documenta 15.

item.title: White House Outlines Covid Vaccine Plan for Children Under 5
item.description: Vaccine deliveries to U.S. states are contingent on the Food and Drug Administration authorizing pediatric doses, a step that could occur as soon as next week.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Federal officials said they expected many children younger than 5 to be vaccinated against the coronavirus by pediatricians and primary care physicians.

item.title: Biden Administration to Set Rules of the Road for Charging Electric Vehicles
item.description: Proposed regulations would require charging stations built with federal dollars to be located no more than 50 miles apart.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia cements its grip on southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Northern Crimean Canal has been reopened.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia’s Land Bridge
item.description: Moscow is trying to deepen its hold on occupied Ukrainian territory in the south.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Russian soldiers near the dam of the North Crimean Canal last month.

item.title: Russia Is Racing to Cement Its Control in Southern Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin says it has rebuilt rail and road links to Crimea, while appointing proxy officials in an effort to create facts on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Northern Crimean Canal was blocked with bags of sand and clay, preventing water from flowing further onto the Russian-occupied Crimean Peninsula.

item.title: A Wider Lens on the MeToo Backlash: Who Pays for Societal Change?
item.description: The same fundamentals apply to patriarchal systems, whether in Hollywood or India: Threats to men’s status can provoke broader resistance than you might think.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Amber Heard leaving Fairfax County Circuit Courthouse after the jury announced its verdicts in Fairfax, Virginia, on June 1.

item.title: As Russia tries to solidify its ‘land bridge,’ Ukraine attempts to push back in the south.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Russian soldiers near the dam of the North Crimean Canal in the Kherson region last month, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Harvey Weinstein Facing Indecent Assault Charges in Britain
item.description: British prosecutors said they authorized criminal charges against Mr. Weinstein for an incident in 1996.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein arriving at a Manhattan courthouse in 2020.

item.title: Iran Turns Off U.N. Surveillance Cameras at Nuclear Site
item.description: The step came as tensions have risen over stalled efforts to revive a 2015 deal that limited Iran’s nuclear activities in exchange for the easing of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: An Iranian flag flying at the Bushehr nuclear power plant in 2019.

item.title: Angela Merkel Says She ‘Won’t Apologize’ for Her Russia Diplomacy
item.description: Ms. Merkel has come under fire for pushing German-Russian business interests during her tenure as chancellor.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Former Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Tuesday in Berlin.

item.title: Australia’s Baby Steps Toward Severing Ties With the Queen
item.description: The new Labor government has established a ministerial position to begin the process of making the country a republic. But the idea is far from the top of its agenda.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia in Canberra last week marking Queen Elizabeth II’s platinum jubilee. It was one of the few events in the country honoring her seven decades on the throne.

item.title: A Supreme Court Preview
item.description: These are the five biggest rulings expected from the Supreme Court in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Anti-abortion protesters at the Supreme Court this week.

item.title: U.S. Lacks a Clear Picture of Ukraine’s War Strategy, Officials Say
item.description: Intelligence agencies know far more about Russia’s military, even as the United States ships billions of dollars in weapons to the Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The gaps in information on the state of Ukraine’s military forces and the government’s strategy in the Donbas have created blind spots for the United States.

item.title: When George W. Bush Confused Russia’s War in Ukraine With Iraq
item.description: A viral gaffe by the former president offers a dark reminder of America’s foreign-policy hypocrisies.
item.dc:creator: Jody Rosen
item.category: Bush, George W, Presidential Library and Museum

item.title: Train Crash in Iran Kills at Least 21
item.description: There were fears that the death toll could rise as rescuers searched the train cars after the deadly accident, which took place about 340 miles southeast of Tehran.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Iranian Red Crescent, via /Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue teams arrived at the crash site near Tabas, in a remote area with poor communications links.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Global economic woes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inventory decisions at Raindrops on Roses in St. Albans, England, are now “less spontaneous, more calculated,” said Karolina Birsen, a manager.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Plan to Regain Power in Israel: Vote Against His Views
item.description: To topple Israel’s government, Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister, is voting down its initiatives — even if he agrees with them.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during a right-wing rally in Jerusalem, in April.

item.title: Biden to Host Latin American Leaders at Summit in Los Angeles
item.description: The president is already the subject of a boycott by some of the region’s most important heads of state, and his agenda is being met with deep skepticism.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administration officials said that President Biden was determined not to ignore the nations south of the United States, particularly the economic devastation in some areas that is destabilizing the region and undermining trade.

item.title: Andrée Geulen, Savior of Jewish Children in Wartime, Dies at 100
item.description: A Belgian teacher, she kept them out of the hands of Nazis, hiding them in convents, monasteries and farms. After the war, she reunited many with their parents.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.media:description: Andrée Geulen with some of the 300 or so Jewish children she rescued in Nazi-occupied Belgium.

item.title: Monkeypox Can Be Airborne, Too
item.description: An abrupt change in C.D.C. guidance underscores a little-known phenomenon: On occasion, monkeypox can be transmitted through aerosols, similar to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scientists say that the monkeypox virus can be airborne, although that route of transmission is only a small contributor to its overall spread.

item.title: Ryanair Asks Travelers to Prove South African Nationality, in Afrikaans
item.description: The choice of a language that had been imposed by the apartheid government and is not even spoken by many South Africans today has set off complaints.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Ryanair cited a “high prevalence of fraudulent South African passports” for the policy.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Strategic Dilemma
item.description: Plus Israel’s unsteady government and Bangladesh’s unfolding fire disaster.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian strikes damaged the frontline town of Soledar.

item.title: Ukraine’s Dilemma: Fight to Hold a Ravaged City, or Pull Back
item.description: Sievierodonetsk, now site of the most intense combat, is “dead,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said, but letting it go might be worse than shedding blood to hold it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Sievierodonetsk last week.

item.title: U.S. Fails to Assess Civilian Deaths in Yemen War, Internal Report Says
item.description: A Saudi-led coalition has killed civilians with U.S. weapons, but the State Department and the Pentagon have fallen short on tracking the deaths, U.S. investigators found.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Saudi-led airstrike hit a prison in Yemen in January and killed at least 70 people, according to Houthi officials and international aid groups.

item.title: What’s Next for Boris Johnson After Narrowly Surviving No-Confidence Vote
item.description: After narrowly winning a no-confidence vote on Monday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a long list of threats to his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressing his cabinet ahead of the weekly cabinet meeting in Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: Kansas Woman Who Joined ISIS Left a ‘Trail of Betrayal’
item.description: Allison Fluke-Ekren, a Muslim convert from Kansas, rose through the ranks of the Islamic State in Syria, where she provided military training to women and girls, including her daughter.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Alexandria Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Allison Fluke-Ekren provided investigators with details about her roles in Syria and Libya as part of a plea deal.

item.title: As the Great Salt Lake Dries Up, Utah Faces An ‘Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
item.description: Climate change and rapid population growth are shrinking the lake, creating a bowl of toxic dust that could poison the air around Salt Lake City.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Bryan Tarnowski
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times

item.title: Before Chickens Were Nuggets, They Were Revered
item.description: The origin of the domestic fowl is more recent than previously thought, but it may have taken them thousands of years to become food.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: Domesticated chickens are descendants of the red jungle fowl, and scientists suspect they were first viewed by humans as marvelous and exotic.

item.title: Sweden’s NATO Bid Gets Tangled Up in a Domestic Political Dispute
item.description: A move by right-wing lawmakers to remove Sweden’s justice minister has been dragged into a battle over the country’s efforts to join the military alliance.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Justice Minister Morgan Johansson, center, after surviving a no-confidence vote in the Swedish Parliament on Tuesday.

item.title: Bodies of Soldiers Killed Defending Mariupol Are Returned to Ukraine.
item.description: In the first official confirmed exchange of war dead, Russia and Ukraine each received about 160 bodies.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol last month.

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Urge Biden to Ensure Saudi Ties Serve U.S.
item.description: A letter to President Biden ahead of his planned trip to Saudi Arabia raises concerns about the kingdom’s cooperation with China on ballistic missiles and its human rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:description: As Saudi Arabia and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman came under increasing criticism after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, the kingdom stepped up its work with China.

item.title: Violence in Rural Mexico Ensnares Doctors, Causing Worker Shortages
item.description: As criminal organizations control more territory in less-populated regions, health care workers, caught in the crossfire, grow reluctant to work in such places.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher
item.media:description: Mexican soldiers patrolled a road in the state of Zacatecas in March, responding to an increase in violence in the municipality of Jerez de Garcia Salinas.

item.title: The prime minister will also have to grapple with an economy at risk of recession.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The financial district in London.

item.title: Gupta Brothers, Accused of Corruption in South Africa, Are Arrested in Dubai
item.description: Atul and Rajesh Gupta had fled South Africa four years ago amid intense law enforcement scrutiny and public outrage over allegations that they facilitated the gutting of state resources.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atul Gupta in Johannesburg in 2010. He and his brother Rajesh have been accused of facilitating public corruption and gutting state resources in South Africa.

item.title: Bangladesh Firefighters Unaware of Chemicals Stored at Shipping Container Depot
item.description: Nine firefighters were among at least 41 people killed in a blaze and a subsequent series of explosions.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: The B.M. Container Depot near Chattogram, Bangladesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: China Tries to Keep Covid Out of Its Grueling College Entrance Exams
item.description: Some students have to travel from locked-down areas to testing sites in special vehicles, while others might be isolated for the exam.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: Students arriving for the college entrance exams, known as the gaokao, in Nanjing, China, on Tuesday.
